This strategy pays off for you BIG TIME because most people DO NOT FOLLOW UP. Like I said, hit-and-runs. 

Sending a few genuine emails to your mentor is a super simple way to stand out from everyone else. It could lead to the opp that changes your life. 

Why wouldn't you do it?

1125413436584800256.text:
In doing so, you become a "superstar" in the eyes of your mentor. They know you come with an ROI and thus, they become your sponsor. 

You're the one they think about when they come across new jobs and opps bc you are always on top of their mind!

1125412037528567808.text:
.@tdufu's advice is this: to follow up not once, not 2x, but THREE times over the course of 1.5 years. 

Each time, express gratitude for their advice. Tell them how it made an impact on your life. Then ask them for another piece of advice.

They will be happy to oblige.

1125411543766712320.text:
Most folks do a hit-and-run with mentors. They reach out with a request to "pick your brain" and then walk off with it.

If you're not sure if the price is worth it, it's fair to ask for a look at previous work. It's fair to ask for case studies and testimonials.

But you don't get to tell me my prices are "too high" instead of saying "I can't afford this."

999931031359803392.text:
If you don't want to buy the lasagna at $X, then you are free to go to another restaurant and order yourself a lasagna there.

It will not be the same lasagna. Choose wisely.

999930615213551616.text:
My rates are my rates. It's the amount I'm willing to offer my services to you for. 

If you want to talk breakdown, lets discuss my tax rates, my business expenses, my cost of living and my financial goals. 

Just kidding. I'm not doing that.

999927290019569665.text:
You don't walk into a restaurant, freak out at how much everything costs and demand a time/labor cost breakdown of a lasagna so you can judge whether it's a Fair Price™.

So why do you think the rules are different when working with freelancers?
